name: Scenario 9: Ransom Note and Impact Assessment
description: After ransomware has encrypted files, you'll need to assess the damage and plan recovery. This scenario shows ransom notes being dropped, encryption completion across multiple hosts, and ransom demands. You'll also see that verified backups are available. Learn to make the critical decision: should you pay the ransom or restore from backups? This scenario teaches best practices for ransomware recovery and why paying attackers is generally not recommended.

events.title: Encryption Complete on 3 Hosts
events.description: All accessible files encrypted on workstation-03, file-server-01, db-server-01

events.title: Ransom Demand Analysis
events.description: Ransom note demands 5 BTC for decryption key

events.title: Backup Verification Available
events.description: Last backup from 6 hours ago verified clean

events.title: Impact Assessment
events.description: Critical systems affected: file-server-01, db-server-01. Non-critical: workstation-03
Ransomware has encrypted files and dropped ransom notes. You have verified backups available. What is your recovery strategy?

options.text: Restore from verified backups and do not pay ransom
options.feedback: Correct! Best practice is to restore from backups.
options.explanation: Restoring from clean backups avoids paying ransom and ensures data integrity.

options.text: Pay the ransom to get decryption key
options.feedback: Not recommended. No guarantee of decryption.
options.explanation: Paying ransom funds criminals and doesn't guarantee recovery.

options.text: Wait to see if decryption tools become available
options.feedback: Too passive with verified backups available.
options.explanation: With verified backups, immediate restoration is the best option.

options.text: Restore only non-critical systems from backup
options.feedback: Partial solution - restore all affected systems.
options.explanation: All affected systems should be restored to ensure complete recovery.
